Tel.: +86 351 7560835; fax: +86 351 7560668. Graphical abstract A systematic investigation was carried on transformation mechanism of surface/bulk structures and carbonaceous species under CO atmosphere over a precipitated Fe-based catalyst, and correlation between iron phases, surface carbon species and FTS activity. Highlights ► The C α and C β species were formed gradually with the conversion of magnetite to χ-Fe5C2 on the surface layers under CO atmosphere. ► The formation of χ-Fe5C2, C α and C β species on the surface layers promoted the catalytic activity. ► The C δ species formed restrained the active sites for FTS reaction. Transformation behavior of carbonaceous species over a precipitated iron-based Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalyst was investigated by Mössbauer effect spectroscopy (MES), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD), temperature-programmed hydrogenation (TPH), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The catalytic activities were tested in a fixed bed reactor. It was found that during carburization the fresh catalyst was firstly reduced from α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, accompanied simultaneously with the formation of atomic (C α ) and polymeric (C β ) carbonaceous species on the surface of the catalyst. With time on stream the Fe3O4 formed in the near-surface regions was converted gradually to χ-Fe5C2, and the amounts of C α and C β species presented an increasing trend. Subsequently, these species were combined partly together to form the graphitic-type (C δ ) carbonaceous species, and the C δ species largely covered on the surface of iron carbides. The formation of iron carbides (especially for χ-Fe5C2), C α and C β species on the surface layers promoted the catalytic activity, whereas the C δ species formed restrained the active sites for FTS reaction. Keywords Transformation behavior Iron-based catalyst Carbonaceous species Iron carbides Mössbauer effect spectroscopy 1 Introduction Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS), which converts syngas derived from coal, natural gas and other carbon-containing materials into liquid fuels and chemicals, is increasingly attracting global interests due to the limited supply and rapidly rising price of crude oil [1,2]. The iron-based catalyst is used widely in the commercial FTS processes because of its high FTS activity, low cost, flexible product distribution and favorable engineering characteristics [3]. Compared to other FTS catalysts (including Co, Ni and Ru), the iron-based catalyst undergoes the most complicated phase changes during pretreatment and FTS [4]. Several iron phases including iron oxides, metallic Fe, and iron carbides have been found to coexist and transform each other during FTS [5–9], which brings the difficulty to understand the correlation between iron phases and catalytic performances. The fresh iron catalyst is composed generally of α-Fe2O3, which is reduced firstly to Fe3O4 irrespective of the pretreatment gas used [9]. The magnetite may be reduced directly to metallic iron in H2 atmosphere or converted to a metastable iron phase of FeO under the interaction of metal-support [10]. In CO or syngas atmosphere iron oxides could be converted to different types of iron carbides (ɛ-Fe2C, ɛ′-Fe2.2C, χ-Fe2.5C or θ-Fe3C). Chen et al. [8] reported that Fe3O4 was reduced firstly to α-Fe, and then converted gradually to iron carbides, whereas the results of Li et al. [11] showed that Fe3O4 was transformed directly to iron carbides without the formation of intermediate metallic iron in syngas atmosphere. Due to extensive phase changes during pretreatment and FTS, the actual nature of active phases is still a controversial one. In recent years, numerous researchers reported that the formation of iron carbides in the surface and bulk regions plays an important role for improving the FTS activity. However, different types of carbonaceous species formed on the surface layers influence obviously microstructures and performances of the iron catalysts. Several types of carbonaceous species have been detected on the surface layers of iron-based catalysts accompanied with extensive phase transformation during FTS [12–17], including (a) adsorbed, atomic carbon (C α ); (b) polymeric (2–3 atoms) surface carbonaceous species (C β ); (c) carbon in iron carbides, either ɛ′-Fe2.2C or χ-Fe2.5C (C γ ); and (d) semi-ordered and moderately ordered graphitic surface carbons (C δ ). The C α and C β species could be carburized into the surface layers and combined with iron phases, and also reacted with free-state H atoms to form the hydrocarbon species. The results of Jin and Datye [18] presented that there was not the formation of carbonaceous species as hematite was reduced to magnetite under CO atmosphere. Accompanied with gradual transformation of the magnetite to iron carbides, different types of carbonaceous species were formed slowly on the catalyst. Yamada et al. [19] found that these amorphous carbonaceous species were formed on the whole surface of catalyst. In addition, the results of Herranz et al. [9] suggested that the C β species was more closely related to FTS activity than Cα, whereas Xu and Bartholomew [16] observed that the distributions of carbonaceous and iron species on the surface of the iron-based catalyst affected obviously the activity–time behavior. However, the relationship between iron carbides in the bulk and surface regions, surface carbon species and the catalytic activity has still not been established. Consequently, the present work focuses on a systematic understanding on transformation mechanism of surface/bulk iron structures and surface carbonaceous species over a precipitated Fe-based catalyst, as well as correlation between iron phases, surface carbon species and the FTS activity. Several techniques, including Mössbauer effect spectroscopy (MES), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature-programmed desorption/hydrogenation (TPD/TPH), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) were applied to investigate the nature of phase compositions in the surface and bulk regions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A typical precipitated iron-based catalyst used in the present study was prepared by a combination of co-precipitation and spray drying method. The detailed preparation method has been described elsewhere [20,21]. In brief, a solution containing Fe(NO3)3 and Mn(NO3)2 with the desired ratio was added into a continuously stirred tank containing de-ionized water at 353±1K. A NH4OH solution was added simultaneously into the tank to maintain the pH value of 9.0±0.1. After precipitation, the precipitate was washed completely, and then filtered. Required amounts of silica sol solution, K2CO3 solution and de-ionized water were successively added into the filtrate, and the mixture was re-slurried and spray-dried. The obtained catalyst precursor was calcined at 773K for 5h. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations 2.2.1 Mössbauer effect spectroscopy In situ MES experiments were carried out in the Mössbauer reactor (MBF-1100) with Mylar windows, which is connected with a set of stainless steel gas lines to allow the in situ measurements using carbon monoxide. The gas flow rate was 60ml/min and the heating rate was 10K/min. The catalyst was firstly carburized in CO atmosphere at 533K and 0.10MPa for different durations. After carburization the sample was cooled in the inert gas to 323K and the Mössbauer spectra of catalysts were recorded at room temperature with a MR 351 constant-acceleration Mössbauer spectrometer (FAST, German), using a 25mCi 57Co (Pd) source. The spectrometer was operated in a symmetric constant acceleration mode. The spectra were collected over 512 channels in the mirror image format. Data analysis was performed using a nonlinear least square fitting routine that models the spectra as a combination of singlets, quadruple doublets and magnetic sextuplets based on a Lorentzian line shape profile. The spectral components were identified based on their isomer shift (IS), quadruple splitting (QS), and magnetic hyperfine field (Hhf). All isomer shift values were reported with respect to metallic iron (α-Fe) at the measurement temperature. Magnetic hyperfine fields were calibrated with the 330kOe field of α-Fe at the ambient temperature. 2.2.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS experiments were performed in an atmospheric quartz tube flow reactor. The conditions of XPS experiments are the same as MES. After carburization the catalyst sample was cooled to 323K in the inert gas, and then transferred into the ultra-high vacuum (UHV) chamber without exposure to air. XPS spectra were taken by a VG MiltiLab 2000 system with Al Kα (1486.6eV) as the X-ray source. The C 1s as a reference signal was adjusted to 284.6eV. 2.2.3 CO temperature-programmed desorption CO-TPD experiments were performed on an Autochem 2920 characterization system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), using He as the carrier gas. The sample loading was 200mg. The gas flow rate was 60ml/min and the heating rate was 10K/min. The pretreatment conditions are the same as MES. After pretreatment the sample was cooled in the carrier gas to 323K. In the subsequent steps, CO adsorption on catalyst was performed for 30min, and then the sample was purged by He for 30min to remove weakly adsorbed species. After this step, CO-TPD was carried out while the temperature was increased to 1073K. 2.2.4 Temperature-programmed hydrogenation TPH experiments were performed in an atmospheric quartz tube flow reactor (5mm i.d.). The outlet of the reactor was connected to a quadruple mass spectrometer through a capillary inlet system. The pretreatment conditions of TPH experiment are the same as MES. After pretreatment the sample was cooled in helium to 323K, and then the gas was switched to high purity hydrogen (the gas flow rate was 60ml/min) while the temperature was increased from 323 to 1073K at a rate of 10K/min. CH4 was monitored using mass signals (m/z) of 15 (CH3 fragments of CH4) instead of 16 to avoid the interference of water vapor and CO2 cracking [22]. 2.2.5 High resolution transmission electron microscopy HRTEM experiments were performed in a Philips CM200 high resolution transmission electronic microscopy with 200kV accelerating voltage. The catalyst was carburized in an atmospheric quartz tube flow reactor (5mm i.d.). The pretreatment conditions are the same as MES. After pretreatment the sample was cooled in helium to room temperature, and then the catalyst was passivated in a stream of 1% O2/99% He (v/v) for 1h. 2.2.6 Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra were collected using an infrared spectrometer (Equinox 55, Bruker, Germany), equipped with KBr optics and a MCTD316 detector at the liquid nitrogen temperature (77K). The infrared cell with ZnSe windows was connected to a feed system with a set of stainless steel gas lines, which allows in situ measurements for CO or CO+H2 adsorption using argon as the flushing gas. In all cases, the gas flows were maintained at 60ml/min by mass flow control meters. All spectra were recorded with a resolution of 4cm−1 and accumulation of 64 scans. 2.3 Reactor system and operating procedures The experiments were conducted in a 12mm i.d. stainless steel fixed bed reactor. For all reaction experiments, 5ml catalyst was mounted in the reactor and was activated using CO at 533K, 0.1MPa and 60ml/min for different durations. After carburization, the syngas passed through the reactor. The feed and tail gases were analyzed by on-line gas chromatographs (GC). H2, CO and CH4 were analyzed on a GC 920 (Shanghai Analyzer Co., PR China) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase structures in the bulk and surface regions In situ MES is used to investigate transformation behavior of bulky iron phases during carburization. Fig. 1 shows the Mössbauer spectra of the fresh catalyst and the samples carburized in CO at 533K, 0.1MPa and 60ml/min for different durations, and Table 1 lists the corresponding parameters. The MES spectra of the fresh catalyst include a sextet and a doublet. The sextet is assigned to the magnetic α-Fe2O3 of the crystallite diameters larger than 13.5nm [23], and the doublet is typical for the superparamagnetic (spm) Fe3+ ions on the non-cubic sites. A large amount of (spm) Fe3+ (82.5%) in the fresh catalyst implies that the α-Fe2O3 crystallites are well dispersed by the incorporation of binder SiO2 [24]. After carburization for 1h, the MES spectra of the sample present two sextets and two doublets. The values of the sextet with Hhf of 487 and 449kOe can be attributed to the tetrahedral (A site) and octahedral sites (B site) of Fe3O4, respectively [23]. The values of the doublet with IS of 0.85mm/s and QS of 1.16mm/s are ascribed to iron oxides in spm state. The formation of magnetite after carburization for 1h indicates that the hematite is firstly reduced to magnetite under CO atmosphere. After carburization over 6h, the MES spectra of samples display three sextets and two doublets. The sextets with IS of 0.19–0.22mm/s, 0.13–0.16mm/s and 0.19–0.28mm/s, Hhf of 215–226kOe, 181–191kOe and 105–116kOe can be attributed to I, II and III sites of χ-Fe5C2, respectively [25,26]. The amount of Fe3O4 decreased slowly, whereas that of iron carbides presented an increasing trend as a function of carburization time, indicating that the magnetite formed is converted gradually to χ-Fe5C2. Smit and Weckhuysen [27] suggested that iron oxides could be converted to η-Fe2C and ɛ-Fe2.2C at mild temperatures, while converted to χ-Fe5C2 above 463K in flowing CO. Therefore, it is possible that the Fe3O4 formed is easily converted to χ-Fe5C2 under presented carburization conditions. In addition, no formation of α-Fe was observed during carburization by in situ MES. Chen et al. [8] investigated phase transformation of the iron catalyst by CO-TPR and found that the Fe3O4 formed was firstly reduced to α-Fe, and then converted to iron carbides. However, the results of Li et al. [11] showed that the magnetite formed was transformed directly to iron carbides under CO/syngas atmosphere without the formation of α-Fe. Due to pretreatment conditions used in the present study is similar with that of Li et al., the magnetite formed may be converted directly to iron carbides without the formation of intermediate metallic iron. XPS is used to investigate transformation behavior of iron structures on the surface layers. Fig. 2 shows the XPS spectra in the Fe 2p regions of the catalysts after pretreatment in CO at 533K, 0.10MPa, 60ml/min and different durations. As shown in Fig. 2, the Fe 2P3/2 peaks of the fresh catalyst appearing at 710.6eV, companied with its shoulder peak at 718.7eV, is attributed to Fe2O3 [28], which is consistent with the bulky structure. After carburization for 1h, the Fe 2P3/2 peak became broad and shifted towards lower binding energies, coupled with the appearance of a weak shoulder peak at 715.4eV, which can be identified as the presence of Fe3O4 [29]. This implies that the hematite on the surface layers is also reduced firstly to magnetite under CO atmosphere. It is known that the hematite is converted to magnetite by the reaction of 3Fe2O3 +CO→2Fe3O4 +CO2. With the removal of oxygen atoms from the particle surface, the oxygen atoms in the bulk regions migrate to the surface layers, resulting in possibly the higher reduction degree of bulky iron oxides. For the catalysts carburized for 6h and above, besides the appearance of the magnetite peak, a narrow peak was observed at 706.9eV, which is characteristic of iron in iron carbides [28]. With increasing carburization time on stream the intensity of magnetite peak decreased, whereas that of iron carbides showed an increasing trend, indicating that the magnetite formed on the surface layers is also transformed gradually to iron carbides. Combined with the results of MES and XPS measurements, it could be considered that during carburization the hematite is reduced firstly to magnetite in the bulk regions, and then for the reduction of iron oxides in the near-surface regions. Subsequently, the magnetite formed on the surface layers is converted continually to iron carbides (especially for χ-Fe5C2), and then for the carburization of iron oxides in the bulk regions. Transformation behavior of iron structures on the surface layers is further investigated by CO-TPD. From Fig. 3 , it was found that the sample after carburization for 1h presented one minor peak at about 573K. According to the results of MES and XPS mentioned above, there is only the formation of magnetite after carburization for 1h in the surface and bulk regions. Thus, the minor peak at about 573K may be attributed to the desorption of adsorbed CO on Fe3O4, which is in agreement with the results of Shaikhutdinov [30]. After carburization over 6h, one new strong peak at about 790K was observed for all of the samples, except for the desorption peak of CO on Fe3O4. The results of XPS measurement indicated that both the Fe3O4 and iron carbides are formed on the surface layers after carburization over 6h, therefore the primary peak at 790K is corresponded probably to the dissociation of CO on iron carbides. It is apparent that the peak intensity of CO adsorption on Fe3O4 decreased slowly, whereas that of CO adsorption on iron carbides increased obviously as a function of carburization time, which further validates transformation behavior of iron phases on the surface layers. 3.2 Carbonaceous species on the surface layers Fig. 4 shows the XPS spectra in the C 1s regions of the catalysts after pretreatment in CO at 533K, 0.10MPa, 60ml/min and different durations. As shown in Fig. 4, a small amount of residual surface carbon as shown by the weak C 1s peak appearing at 284.6eV remained on the fresh catalyst, which could arise from minor impurities during catalyst preparation. After carburization for 1h, the intensity of surface carbon increased obviously, implying that CO pretreatment for 1h promotes the formation of surface carbonaceous species. Janbroers et al. [17] reported that the surface carbonaceous species were formed only on the iron carbides, but not on the iron oxides. However, the results in the present study indicate that there was only the formation of magnetite on the surface layers after carburization for 1h, and the surface carbon was formed on the surface of magnetite. Deng et al. [31] found that H-assisted CO dissociation (CO+H→CHO, CHO→CH+O) has lower barrier than CO direct dissociation. In other words, the direct dissociation of CO is difficult comparatively on the surface of iron-based catalysts. Our previous results [32] showed that increasing CO partial pressure facilitated the Boudouard reaction, promoting the formation of surface carbon. Therefore, the formation of surface carbon in pure CO atmosphere may be stemmed from the Boudouard reaction (2CO→C+CO2). With the prolonging of carburization time the amounts of surface carbonaceous species presented a continually increasing trend. Additionally, with the proceeding of carburization the C 1s peak shifted gradually towards lower binding energies (283.5eV) and the peak intensity increased obviously. The C 1s peak at 283.5eV is assigned to carbon in the iron carbides, which indicates that a large number of surface carbonaceous species formed converted gradually to iron carbides as a function of carburization time. TPH is used to investigate different carbonaceous species formed on the surface layers. The TPH curves of the catalysts carburized for different durations are showed in Fig. 5 , while corresponding deconvoluted spectra are presented in Fig. 6 . Peak temperatures and fractional peak areas are tabulated in Table 2 . From Fig. 5 it can be seen that the catalyst carburized for 1h has one main peak and the sample carburized for 6h has three intense peaks. The catalyst sample carburized for 12h has five peaks and the catalyst carburized for 24h has one main peak and two shoulder peaks. The peaks in the temperature range of 500–650K are attributed to the adsorption of atomic (C α ) and polymeric (C β ) carbonaceous species [12]. Two intense peaks at 700–830K correspond to iron carbides (C γ ), and the shoulder peak at about 860K is ascribed to the appearance of graphitic carbonaceous species (C δ ) [16]. According to the results shown in Fig. 6 and Table 2, carburization for 1h leads to the formation of C α and C β species on the surface layers without the formation of iron carbides. Therefore, the surface carbonaceous species formed after carburization for 1h characterized by XPS is attributed to the atomic and polymeric carbonaceous species. With time on stream the amounts of C α and C β species increased gradually, accompanied with the formation of iron carbide. Combined with the results of MES, it considers that the iron carbide formed is attributed to χ-Fe5C2, which may be stemmed from the combination of iron and C α /C β species. Subsequently, with the continual increasing of χ-Fe5C2 concentration, the C δ species were formed gradually on the catalyst. As carburization time increased to 24h, the C β , C γ and C δ species were mainly formed on the surface layers, while the C α species disappeared. To further validate transforming correlation of different carbonaceous species, HRTEM is used to analyze visually formation behavior of the carbonaceous species. Fig. 7a shows a high magnification TEM view of the fresh catalyst. The diffraction spacings about 3.7Å were observed obviously, which are attributed to the crystallites of hematite [33]. After carburization for 1h, it can be seen (Fig. 7b) that most regions of the sample appear unchanged compared to the fresh catalyst. In certain regions the diffraction spacings (about 2.5Å) of Fe3O4 were appeared [33], indicating that the hematite on the surface layers was reduced partly to Fe3O4. This is in well agreement with the results of MES and XPS. In addition, the formation of surface carbon was observed on the surface of hematite and magnetite [18]. Combined with the results of TPH and XPS, it is considered that the surface carbon formed could be attributed to the C α and/or C β species. The thickness of surface carbon covered on the catalyst is about 1nm. As carburization time increased to 6h (Fig. 7c), except for the appearance of diffraction spacings of hematite and magnetite, few diffraction spacings about 2.1Å were appeared on the surface layers, which are ascribed to the crystallites of iron carbides [33]. The formation of iron carbides may be stemmed directly from the carburization of Fe3O4. It is possible that part of the atomic and polymeric carbonaceous species migrate into the near-surface layers and combine with magnetite to form iron carbides. In addition, these surface carbonaceous species covered on the surface of Fe3O4 and iron carbides, and their thickness increased to 2–3nm, indicating that increasing carburization time facilitates the formation of surface carbonaceous species. As carburization time was prolonged to 12h (Fig. 7d), the diffraction spacings of hematite disappeared almost, and a large number of diffraction spacings of magnetite and iron carbides were observed on the surface layers. On the other hand, the thickness of surface carbon increased to about 5nm, and part of surface carbonaceous species became more structured. The results of TPH mentioned above showed that there was the formation of graphitic-type carbonaceous species after carburization for 12h. Therefore, the C α and C β species formed could be combined partly together to form the semi-ordered or moderately ordered sheets. After carburization for 24h (Fig. 7e) it is apparent that large amounts of surface carbon covered on the surface of iron carbides. Combined with the characterization results in the bulk, near-surface and outer-surface layers, a clear scene may be obtained on transformation behavior of the carbonaceous species (Fig. 8 ). The hematite is reduced firstly to Fe3O4 in the bulk and surface regions, simultaneously followed with the formation of surface carbon on the catalyst, which stems mainly from the Boudouard reaction. With the proceeding of carburization the Fe3O4 formed is converted to iron carbides (especially for χ-Fe5C2) from surface layers to bulk regions, and the amorphous (C α and/or C β ) carbonaceous species are formed gradually on the surface layers. Subsequently, these C α and C β species combine partly together to form the graphitic-type carbonaceous species, and large amounts of the C δ species cover ultimately on the surface of iron carbides. 3.3 Relationship between phase structures and FTS activity The catalytic activities of the catalysts carburized for different durations are shown in Fig. 9 . It can be seen that the FTS activity of the catalyst carburized for 1h was the lowest (only 30%). With the prolonging of carburization time, the catalytic activity increased gradually. As carburization time increased to 12h, the catalyst presented the highest FTS activity (72%). Subsequently, the FTS activity of the catalyst carburized for 24h remained unchanged almost. According to the characteristic results, it is known that the catalyst carburized for 1h comprised the magnetite and surface C α /C β species. After exposure to syngas the catalytic activity was the lowest. With the gradual formation of iron carbides and increasing amounts of C α /C β species on the surface of magnetite, the FTS activity presented an increasing trend, suggesting that the formation of iron carbides (especially for χ-Fe5C2) and C α /C β species on the surface layers provides the active sites, promoting the FTS activity. In addition, there was the formation of graphitic-type carbonaceous species as carburization time increased to 12h, while the catalytic activity remained unchanged, implying that the formation of C δ species has not arrived the degree to restrain the catalyst activity. In order to further investigate relationship between surface phase structures and FTS activity, the catalysts pretreated under different CO contents are characterized by DRIFTS. Fig. 10 shows the infrared spectra of CO adsorption on the catalyst samples. As shown in Fig. 10, several bands at 1650, 1635, 1571, 1558, 1540, 1507, 1395, 1375 and 1302cm−1 appear on all of the catalysts after CO adsorption. The bands at 1650, 1635 and 1302cm−1 can be assigned to carbonates formed on surface basic sites [34]. 1571 and 1395cm−1 may be assigned to CH bending modes of the hydrocarbons [35]. The bands at 1558, 1540, 1507, and 1375cm−1 may be ascribed to symmetric and symmetric bending modes of CH x species (x =2 or 3) [35,36]. Apparently, it can be found that the intensity of hydrocarbon species presented a decreasing trend with the increase in CO content, accompanied with no obvious change for the intensity of carbonates. Since no hydrogen is admitted during CO adsorption measurement, the appearance of hydrogen element in hydrocarbon species stems from the pretreatment process. With the increase in CO content under syngas atmosphere, the hydrogen content decreases gradually. Thus, the chemical-adsorptive hydrogen atoms in the catalyst decrease accordingly, resulting in the decrease in hydrocarbon species concentration on the surface. As the syngas (H2/CO=1.2) adsorbs on the surface of catalysts, the adsorption behavior undergoes an obvious change. From Fig. 11 , it can be clearly seen that the intensity of hydrocarbon species increased slightly with the increase in CO content, which presented an opposite trend compared to the above analysis. As the syngas is adsorbed on the surface of catalyst, large amounts of H2 and CO are provided, therefore, the catalyst with more active sites would produce more hydrocarbon species. It is well known that with the increase in CO content, the magnetite formed is converted to iron carbides in the surface and bulk regions. Correspondingly, the catalyst pretreated under higher CO content produces more hydrocarbon species on the surface after adsorption of syngas, which further validates that the formation of more iron carbides (especially for χ-Fe5C2) on the surface layers provides more active sites, promoting the formation of hydrocarbon species. To further investigate the influence of surface carbon depositions on the FTS activity, the infrared spectra of syngas (H2/CO=1.2) adsorption on CO-activated catalysts are shown in Fig. 12 . It can be found that the intensity of hydrocarbon species adsorbed on the surface is lower for the catalyst reduced in pure CO compared to that for the catalyst reduced in 10% CO/90% N2. Compared to the catalyst activated at lower CO concentration, pretreatment at higher CO concentration results in the formation of more iron carbides, which should provide more active sites for FTS reaction. However, the results of present study indicate that the pure CO (100%) activated catalyst yields less hydrocarbon species. It is possible that activation in pure CO results in the formation of more graphitic carbonaceous species, blocking the access of the reactants to the active sites and restraining the formation of hydrocarbon species. 4 Conclusions The characterization of a typical precipitated iron catalyst by some techniques provided unique insights on carburization mechanism of phase compositions in the surface and bulk regions and relationship between surface phase structures and FTS activity. Firstly, the hematite in the fresh catalyst was reduced to magnetite in the surface and bulk regions under CO atmosphere. At the same time, some amorphous (C α and C β ) carbonaceous species were formed on the surface layers by the Boudouard reaction. Subsequently, the magnetite on the surface layers converted gradually to iron carbides, with durative increase in concentrations of the C α and C β species. During further carburization the amorphous carbonaceous species partly converted to the graphitic-type carbonaceous species. These ordered species increased continually in concentration as a function of carburization time, and large amounts of species covered the surface of iron carbides. The formation of χ-Fe5C2 and C α /C β species on the surface layers provides the active sites, promoting the formation of hydrocarbon species, while gradual conversion of these amorphous species to graphitic-type carbonaceous species might block the access of syngas to the active sites, inducing the decrease in hydrocarbon species concentration. coredata.dc:description: Transformation behavior of carbonaceous species over a precipitated iron-based Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalyst was investigated by Mössbauer effect spectroscopy (MES), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD), temperature-programmed hydrogenation (TPH), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The catalytic activities were tested in a fixed bed reactor. It was found that during carburization the fresh catalyst was firstly reduced from α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, accompanied simultaneously with the formation of atomic (C α ) and polymeric (C β ) carbonaceous species on the surface of the catalyst. With time on stream the Fe3O4 formed in the near-surface regions was converted gradually to χ-Fe5C2, and the amounts of C α and C β species presented an increasing trend. Subsequently, these species were combined partly together to form the graphitic-type (C δ ) carbonaceous species, and the C δ species largely covered on the surface of iron carbides. The formation of iron carbides (especially for χ-Fe5C2), C α and C β species on the surface layers promoted the catalytic activity, whereas the C δ species formed restrained the active sites for FTS reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Transformation of carbonaceous species and its influence on catalytic performance for iron-based Fischer–Tropsch synthesis catalyst
